Generations of his family had toiled on this land, but Kamal, armed with a B.Sc. in Agriculture from Mahatma Phule Krishi Vidyapeeth, Rahuri, wanted to do things differently. He dreamt of organic farming, a stark contrast to the chemical-laden practices that had become commonplace.

unnormalised: His grandfather, Dada, initially scoffed. "Organic? How will you feed the family? Yields will plummet! Fertilizer Rs. 5000 per bag ensures a good harvest." Dada remembered the Green Revolution, a time when chemical fertilizers and pesticides promised bountiful crops and escaped the looming shadow of food scarcity.

unnormalised: Kamal, however, was convinced. He had seen the impact of those chemicals - the depleted soil, the contaminated water, the illnesses plaguing his village. He started small, dedicating just 1 acre out of his 10-acre holding to organic methods. He used cow dung manure from his own cattle, vermicompost, and neem-based pesticides. He painstakingly learned techniques like crop rotation and companion planting, remembering stories Dada had told him about traditional practices.

unnormalised: The first year was tough. The yield was lower than expected, and pests seemed to thrive. Dada grumbled, "I told you so! This is a waste of time and effort." But Kamal persevered. He consulted Dr. Patil, a renowned organic farming expert from the local Krishi Vigyan Kendra, who advised him on soil management and pest control.

unnormalised: Slowly, things started to improve. The soil regained its fertility, earthworms reappeared, and the crops became more resilient. Kamal started selling his organic produce at a farmer's market in Pune, 150 km away. The demand was high, and people were willing to pay a premium for pesticide-free food. He even experimented with intercropping, planting legumes like moong bean between rows of sugarcane, enriching the soil with nitrogen.

unnormalised: Five years later, Kamal’s entire farm is organic. The yields are comparable to conventional farming, and the soil is thriving. He now teaches other farmers in his village about organic methods, proving that sustainable agriculture is not just a romantic ideal but a viable and profitable way of life. His farm, including a newly constructed 2000 sq ft greenhouse for exotic vegetables, is a testament to his dedication.
